Project Topic
We did a study looking at how many people in Turkey took their own lives from 2002 to 2022. We wanted to understand if the increase in stress and the more news about suicide are making it seem like more people are doing it, or if there’s a real increase in suicides.
In our data set, we have details about when people did suicide, why they did it, how old they were, and if they were male or female. This data helps us see the patterns and changes in suicide rates over the twenty years. We can use this data to understand why people do this and how we can help them better.

Data has been divided into multiple categories
Source of the data set is reliable (TUİK)
Data set didn’t need any preprocessing

title: Data
section: What are the categories of this data set?
text:
What are the categories of this data set?
The reasons for suicides in this dataset are categorized into eight groups:

Illness
Family incompatibility
Economic problems
Business failure
Emotional relationships and not marrying the person wanted
Educational failure
Other
Unknown.

title: Data
section: What are the age groups of this data set?

<15
15-19
20-24
25-29
30-34
35-39
40-44
45-49
50-54
55-59
60-64
65-69
70-74
+75.

title: Data
text:
What is our aim?
By leveraging this dataset, we aim to answer the following questions:

Suicide rates by gender regardless of age and reason
Suicide rates by age regardless of gender and reason
Suicide rates by reasons regardless of age and gender
The most observed reason for suicides for females/males
The most observed reason for suicides for teenagers

By obtaining answers to these questions, we can understand how to approach preventing suicides for different age groups and genders.

We used the bar plot method to compare suicides by reason regardless of gender and age group. You can find the graph and the code we used below.

This line chart shows the change in the causes of suicide over the years.

# Keep only 3 names
  a = filter(data,Year != "2002",Year!="2003",`Age group`=="Total", Sex == "Total")
  a1 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$Illness,Cause="Illness")
  a2 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$`Family incompatibility`,Cause="Family")
  a3 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$`Economic problems`,Cause="Economy")
  a4 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$`Business failure`,Cause="Business")
  a5 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$`Emotional relationship and not marrying the person wanted`,Cause="Emotional")
  a6 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$`Educational failure`,Cause="Education")
  a7 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$Other,Cause="Other")
  a8 = data.frame(Year=a$Year,Total=a$Unknown,Cause="Unknown")
  cause = rbind(a1,a2,a3,a4,a5,a6,a7,a8,deparse.level = 0)




Code
graph <- cause %>% 
    filter(Cause %in% c("Illness","Family","Economy","Business","Emotional","Education","Other","Unknown"))
  b = as.numeric(cause$Total)
  c = ifelse(is.na(b),0,b)
  graph %>%
    ggplot( aes(x=Year, y=c, group=Cause, color=Cause)) +
      geom_line() +
      ylab("Number of Suicides") +
      scale_y_log10() +
      ggtitle("Number of Suicides by Reasons")





We can say that while the number of suicides due to business and education has decreased over time, the number of other suicides has remained almost constant.
We used a pie chart to better analyze the ratios


Code
# Pie Chart with Percentages
#| codefold: true
#| output: false
slices <- c(
  sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$Illness)),0,as.numeric(a$Illness))),
  sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$`Family incompatibility`)),0,as.numeric(a$`Family incompatibility`))) ,
  sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$`Economic problems`)),0,as.numeric(a$`Economic problems`))),
  sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$`Business failure`)),0,as.numeric(a$`Business failure`))),
  sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$`Emotional relationship and not marrying the person wanted`)),0,as.numeric(a$`Emotional relationship and not marrying the person wanted`))),
  sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$`Educational failure`)),0,as.numeric(a$`Educational failure`))),
  sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$Other)),0,as.numeric(a$Other))),sum(ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(a$Unknown)),0,as.numeric(a$Unknown))))

lbls <- c("Illness","Family","Economy","Business","Emotional","Education","Other","Unknown")
pct <- round(slices/sum(slices)*100)
lbls <- paste(lbls, pct)
# add percents to labels
lbls <- paste(lbls,"%",sep="") # ad % to labels




Code
pie(slices,labels = lbls, col=rainbow(length(lbls)),
   main="Pie Chart of Suicide Reasons",cex=0.8)





As a result, we see that if we ignore the unknowns, the Illness has a huge dominance.
